pageTextData.title:
Welcome to the
Virtual Museum of Firearms.
pageTextData.description: This is an unofficial collection of 3D models and renders of historical firearms inspired to the original collection at the Royal Armouries Museum, in Leeds, UK.

pageTextData.title: Explore a historical collection.
pageTextData.description: Navigate to the Models section to access a 3D visualisation of the geometry of the 4 firearms included in this collection, or explore the Gallery for a range of images rendered with optimal lighting and viewpoints.

pageTextData.title: About
pageTextData.description: This website was created using HTML5, CSS3, Javascript (with JQuery), AJAX, PHP7 and SQLite with an MVC design pattern. The framework used is Bootstrap 4. The IDE used were JetBrains PhpStorm 2019, Sublime Text 3 and Visual Studio Code. The 3D objects are modelled using Autodesk 3D Studio Max 2017 and rendered using NVidia Mental Ray. The textures were edited using Adobe Photoshop. The 3D models include VRML97 Helpers, are tested on instantreality and embedded using the XML-based technology X3DOM.

pageTextData.title: 3D Models
pageTextData.description:
The 3D models displayed below are built in 3D Studio Max and use VRML97 Helpers for web interaction. They are embedded with the XML-based technology X3DOM.
Click and drag to inspect the model. Click on the model for redirection to its Royal Armouries web page. Press R to reset the viewpoint. Use the buttons and sliders below to change camera view, toggle lights, animation and wireframe mode, or to apply a layer of fog on the model.

pageTextData.title: Gallery
pageTextData.description: The 3D images displayed below are rendered with NVidia Mental Ray. Switch between Slideshow and Cards view using the apposite buttons. When in Slideshow mode, you can navigate the images using the Prev and Next buttons below. When in Cards mode, you can click on each card to open a lightbox and see the image in full resolution (1920 x 1080).

pageTextData.title: Extras
pageTextData.description:
In working on this website, all measures were taken to ensure a high quality of navigation, usability and user experience. In particular,
  • 3D Geometry:
    The objects selected for modelling presented a high degree of complexity, and were built with performance in mind. In this, each model contains the lowest amount of polys to maintain the realistic look that characterises this Web 3D experience.
  • Photorealistic texturing & rendering:
    The rendering takes advantage of photorealistic textures, edited using Photoshop for brightness, contrast, curves, colour correction and background, to provide an immersive experience. Additionally, a cloth simulation was made using physics and Cloth modifiers to create beautiful and realistic renders for each model.
  • CSS Styling:
    The 3D App was designed with usability and user experience in mind. Fluid grid layouts were used where appropriate, and input features were redesigned to override the default Bootstrap 4 ones (i.e. by recreating a style and colour theme and respecting it throughout the app) to create a unique experience.
    • Lightboxes were used to improve the gallery navigation experience;
    • Text and Image Keyframe-Based Animations were implemented to improve the aesthetic of the home page;
    • A Sidebar was implemented because considered a better, more user-friendly way of navigating when designing the 3D App to be Mobile-First;
    • Smooth Transitions Between Content were achieved using the fadeIn() JQuery function when fetching and swapping divs within the 3D App;
    • Both Slideshow & Cards Gallery Navigation Modes were provided to tailor the experience to all kind of users;
    • Full Responsiveness allows the 3D App to be experienced optimally cross-platform, on all devices and screen sizes.
  • Javascript/JQuery Interactivity & Relation to MVC Design Pattern: Data included in the 3D App is read from a JSON file, stored in a SQLite database and fetched to the front-end using JQuery. This ensures a smooth content-insertion workflow, which takes advantage of an extended MVC design pattern and of an easy to manage database that includes all CRUD functions needed for the implementation. Content in the SPA is swapped using JQuery effects to improve the user experience.
  • 3D Interactivity: Animations are designed to be on theme with the object. Different camera views and lights are provided for user interaction, together with extra interactions such as a fog modifier. AnchorPoints were used to allow the user to click on the model to navigate to the webpage of the Royal Armouries Museum. Maximum care was taken with customised pivot points (for geometry, animation and with the VRML97 Helpers) to allow for optimal exporting and web interaction experience.

pageTextData.title: Centrefire six-shot revolver - Smith & Wesson New Model No.3 Target
pageTextData.provenance: Manufactured by S&W in 1888 or 1889 Supplied to Winans Jan 5 1893 Acquired by Flinders Petrie date unknown Gifted to Carl Pape date unknown Retained by his family Acquired by Royal Armouries under deposit number A0290
pageTextData.description: A cased example of a Target model wth 6.5 barrel and barleycorn style front sight. High quality blue finish and with colour case-hardened hammer. It is engraved with the owners initials and competition details.

pageTextData.title: Centrefire self-loading pistol - Makarov PM Darra copy
pageTextData.provenance: Gifted by the Ministry of Defence, February 2016
pageTextData.description: This Pakistani or Afghani copy or refurbished Makarov PM is a medium-size pistol with a straight blowback action and is of all steel construction with a frame-fixed barrel. In a blowback designs such as this, the only force holding the slide closed is that of the recoil spring wrapped around the barrel; as a consequence upon firing the barrel and slide do not have to unlock.
